column4: Home Energy Efficiency Assessment (in partnership with Home Efficiency Australia)
column6:
The Council partnered with Home Efficiency Australia to deliver the Home Energy Efficiency Assessment scheme.

After users complete an energy assessment digitally, Home Efficiency Australia provides insight into eligible deals.
column9:
$100 discount off any of the following:
- Heat pump hot water system
- Air conditioning
- Solar and battery storage
- Home insulation
column10:
Property must be in the City of Adelaide (postcode 5000 or 5006).

Awarded on a first-come first-served basis.
column13: Home Efficiency Australia; Adelaide City Council
column15: The Adelaide Home Efficiency program is a Recipient of the Carbon Neutral Catalyst Fund.

column6: The City of Adelaide reimburses 50% of the cost to replace gas appliances with electric or solar powered units, up to a maximum of $1,000 for residential households.
column9:
Rebate options available:
- Appliance electrification (50% up to $1,000 for residential replacement and up to $5,000 for commercial replacement that replace gas appliances)
- Business sustainability training (50% up to $200 for small business)
- Home energy or sustainability assessment (50% up to $200)
- Energy monitoring systems (50% up to $100 for stand-alone)
- Smart water meter with real-time digital capabilities (50% up to $1,000)
- Energy Smart Buildings for strata managed properties ($25,000 for a whole of building approach – business case required)

There’s $200,000 available in 2023 under the Incentives for Sustainability.
column10: Property must be located within the City of Adelaide LGA (postcodes 5000 and 5006), and applications must be submitted within 12 months of project completion.
column14: In 2023, the Council Mayor stated: "Council’s Incentives for Sustainability has been incredibly popular, providing more than $1.5 million in rebates to over 700 different projects since 2015".

column4: Home Energy Tookit & Energy Savings Kit
column6: Residents can borrow the tookits from the Council library.
column10: Residents must live in the Adelaide Hills LGA.

column6: The Council partnered with ShineHub to deliver the 2024 Solar Bulk Buy program, which is a community renewables program for homes specifically providing discounted solar and battery through ShineHub (or other suppliers selected by resident).
column10: Property must be in the City of Charles Sturt LGA.
Property must be in the City of Holdfast Bay LGA.

column6: Residents can borrow the tookit from the Council's libraries.
column10: Residents must live in the City of Marion LGA.

column6:
The Council has partnered with ShineHub, who is providing solar bulk buy for solar panel, battery, and virtual power plant solutions for residents, community battery solutions for Council and electric vehicle chargers for the council area.

The Flash Bulk Buy August 2024 was the last opportunity for residents to lock in the 2024 Bulk Buy pricing.
column14: Since 2022, the Council has run three community bulk buys reaching over 4,000 residents and resulting in over 900 households signing up for solar panels, batteries and joining a virtual power plant. The carbon emission reductions from the solar panel systems are 1,700tCO2e which is the equivalent of taking 405 petrol-powered vehicles off the road for one year. Collectively households are saving over $2 million off their energy bills annually

column15:
New homes in the recently rezoned LGA will be exempt from the NCC energy requirements (7 star energy requirement) as it would cause new builds to become too expensive:

The project involves leaving temperature loggers in various rooms within houses of different build materials (e.g. limestone, timber, brick) to test their energy efficiency in the Mount Gambier climate
Residents can apply for a solar rebate from the council after the installation is complete.
